Your blood pressure can give you an indication of your heart and overall health. In England and Wales, every year there are over 500,000 new cases of high blood pressure – of which around 270,000 will be the people are not even aware they are affected.
This is called ‘silent hypertension.’
In the UK, high blood pressure is the main risk factor for CVD and the main reason for heart attacks, strokes, heart failure and dementia.
As discussed above, high blood pressure can damage arterial walls, causing fatty deposits to build up and narrowing blood vessels, which can ultimately lead to CHD.
You have an increased risk of developing high blood pressure if a close relative such as a parent or sibling has high blood pressure. High blood pressure can also be passed between generations.
In the UK, an estimated 14 to 16 million people have high blood pressure. However, one in five people don’t know they have it.
If you have diabetes, blood glucose control is a key prevention measure: a blood glucose level generally <5.5 mmol/L, fasting blood glucose level <7.0 mmol/L or HbA1c <6.5% is optimal for preventing or delaying the development of microvascular and macrovascular disease complications.

The more blood your heart needs to pump, the more the walls of the heart muscle have to stretch and thicken, which in the long term makes the heart less efficient at pumping blood.
This increased strain on the heart also makes it harder for the blood to flow through the narrowed blood vessels and leads to higher blood pressure. This, in turn, makes the heart work even harder and the cycle continues.

**Elaborated textbook-level solution:** Smoking cessation is a critical element in the management of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk because tobacco use considerably elevates the likelihood of developing CVD conditions, including heart attacks, strokes, and peripheral vascular disease. Nicotine and other chemicals in cigarettes cause damage to the lining of blood vessels, promote the accumulation of plaque (atherosclerosis), raise blood pressure, impede normal oxygen flow to the heart due to narrowed blood vessels, and increase the risk of blood clot formation.

In support of smoking cessation, healthcare providers can recommend a variety of strategies. First, a thorough assessment of readiness to quit and individualized counseling are essential. Pharmacotherapy options, such as nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), bupropion, or varenicline, can be adjuncts to behavioral interventions.
